abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:italic>KCNJ16</jats:italic>encodes K<jats:sub>ir</jats:sub>5.1 and acts in combination with K<jats:sub>ir</jats:sub>4.1, encoded by<jats:italic>KCNJ10</jats:italic>, to form an inwardly rectifying K<jats:sup>+</jats:sup>channel expressed at the basolateral membrane of epithelial cells in the distal nephron. This K<jats:sub>ir</jats:sub>4.1/K<jats:sub>ir</jats:sub>5.1 channel is critical for controlling basolateral membrane potential and K<jats:sup>+</jats:sup>recycling, the latter coupled to Na-K-ATPase activity, which determines renal Na<jats:sup>+</jats:sup>handling. Previous work has shown that<jats:italic>Kcnj16</jats:italic><jats:sup>−/−</jats:sup>mice and SS<jats:sup><jats:italic>Kcnj16</jats:italic>−/−</jats:sup>rats demonstrate hypokalemic, hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis. Here, we present the first report of a patient identified to have biallelic loss-of-function variants in<jats:italic>KCNJ16</jats:italic>by whole exome sequencing who presented with chronic metabolic acidosis with exacerbations triggered by minor infections.</jats:p>

title: Biallelic loss-of-function variants in KCNJ16 presenting with hypokalemic metabolic acidosis
